description: Uncertain. Possibly from Middle English *lavand, *lavant, lavande, present participle of Middle English laven (“to stream, pour out a stream, wash”), from Old English lafian (“to pour water on, wash, lave, bathe, ladle out”), equivalent to lave +‎ -and; or from Old French lavant, present participle of laver (“to wash”). See lave.

entries.meaning: (UK dialectal) A shallow or more or less intermittent spring.
(UK dialectal) A violent flow or rush of water.
examples: How it did rain! It ran down the street in a lavant.
